  • We require that start nodes for each filter to satisfy two criteria:(a) the start point s≡st(f)s \equiv st(f)s≡st(f) for a query with a single filter fff should be associated with that filter; (b) no point in PPP should be the start point for too many filter labels, the load of routing queries with different filters should be shared across many points so that we can build a graph of small bounded maximum degree which caters to all filter labels. We achieve this using a simple randomized load balancing algorithm:
  • The pruning procedure relies on the following principle:
  • Given a query xqx_qxq​ and a set of labels FqF_qFq​, we are required to output the kkk approximate nearest neighbors of xqx_qxq​, where each point in the outputs shares at least one label with FqF_qFq​. The search procedure takes in a set SSS of start nodes. For a query with label set FqF_qFq​, the set SSS is typically st(f):f∈Fq{st(f): f \in F_q}st(f):f∈Fq​, where st(f)st(f)st(f) is the designated start node for label f \n F computed during index construction.

StichedVamana Algorithm

  The StichedVamana algorithm takes a bulk-indexing approach and only can be used when the point set is known ahead of time. It builds a separate Vamana index over each point set PfP_fPf​ of all points associated with each filter fff, and overlays them into a graph whose edges are the unin of the edges in filter-specific graphs.

Futures

  • Support for filter sets larger than several thousands and support for more complex SQL-like filter expressions with efficiency of graph indices remain challenging open problems
  • 本文构建了一种耦合索引来优化标量-向量过滤，但是出发点相对简单，局促在 “exact match with one filter”，并没有普遍适应各种标量过滤条件的可能，而且对于 “exact match + union” 的情况也直接 remain it for future 了

References

  • GOLLAPUDI S, KARIA N, SIVASHANKAR V, 等. Filtered-DiskANN: Graph Algorithms for Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search with Filters[C/OL]//Proceedings of the ACM Web Conference 2023. Austin TX USA: ACM, 2023: 3406-3416[2025-05-09]. https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3543507.3583552.

entry.title: VBASE, Unifying Online Vector Similarity Search and Relational Queries vis Relaxed Monotonicity
entry.content:
Overview

  An increasing need for more sophisticated vector queries requires integrating vector search systems with relational databases. However, high-dimensional vector indices do exhibit monotonicity, a critical property of coventional indices.The lack of monotonicity forces existing vector systems to rely on monotonicity-preserving tentative indices, set up temporarily for a target vector’s TopK nearest neighbors, to faciliate queries.
  This paper preposes VBASE, a system that efficiently supports complex queries of both approximate similarity search and relational operators. VABSE identifies a common property, relaxed monotonicity, to unify two seemingling incompatible systems.[ 基于松弛一致性，将向量索引和标量索引以一种统一的方式集成到数据库中 ]

Details

Division Between Databases and Vector Search Systems

  Vector search and database systems differ in their ways of using index, a critical structure to speed up queries. An important property of conventional indices like B-tree is monotonicity. This property ensures that a query can traverse the data-set guided by an index monotonically along a certain directrion. This often avoids total data scan, therefore enables efficient query execution.
  However, it is prohibitively expensive for high-dimensional vector indices to preserve monotonicity, because of the curse of dimensionality. Instead, they are often organized as a graph or cluster-based irregular structure, which follows monotonicity approximately. Traversing such vector indices does not gurantee a strict monotonic order in terms of distances to a target vector, but it enbales a system to efficiently determine when it’s unlikely for new traversals to reach closer vectors to a target than the current K ones.

VABSE Design

Relaxed Monotonicity

  There is a common two-pahse traversal pattern in most vector indices: In the first phase, the index tracersal approaches the target region approximately in spite of large oscillations in vector distances; In the second phase, the index traversal stabilizes and steadily departs from the target vector region in an approximate way. Thus a TopK search query could terminate early when it enters the second phase as further traversals are unlikely to identify more similar vectors.

  To determine whther it enters phase two, a query needs to understand RqR_qRq​, the radius of the neighbor sphere centered around qqq, and whether MqsM_{q}^{s}Mqs​, the distance between the query’s current index traversal position(denoted as traversal step sss) and qqq, is greater than RqR_qRq​, i.e., it is traversing beyond the neighborhood of qqq.
  Formally, RqR_qRq​ the radius of qqq’s neighborhood, is defined as:

Rq=Max(TopE({Distance(q,vj)∣j∈[1,s−1]}))[Eq1]R_q = \text{Max}(\text{Top}E(\{\text{Distance}(q, v_j) | j \in [1, s - 1]\})) [Eq1]Rq​=Max(TopE({Distance(q,vj​)∣j∈[1,s−1]}))[Eq1]

  where TopETopETopE denotes the nearest neighbrs of qqq observed during the traversal, supposing that the traversal has reached step sss so far. During an index traversal, the sphere’s radius RqR_qRq​ would gradually decrease during phase 1, and becomes stable during phase 2.
  Mathametically, MqsM_{q}^{s}Mqs​ is defined as the median distance to qqq of all vectors traversed in the most recent www steps, i.e., the traversal window:

Mqs=Median({Distance(q,vi)∣i∈[s−w+1,s]})[Eq2]M^s_q = \text{Median}(\{\text{Distance}(q, v_i) | i \in [s - w + 1, s]\}) [Eq2]Mqs​=Median({Distance(q,vi​)∣i∈[s−w+1,s]})[Eq2]

  where Distance(q,vi)Distance(q,v_i)Distance(q,vi​) denotes the distance between qqq and vector viv_ivi​, traversed in the past traversal window.
  Taking Eq1 and Eq2 together, we define Relaxed Monotonicity as:

∃s,Mqt≥Rq,∀t≥s[Eq3]\exists s, M^t_q \geq R_q, \forall t \geq s [Eq3]∃s,Mqt​≥Rq​,∀t≥s[Eq3]

  In other words, a vector index follows relaxed monotonicity is there exists a certain index traversal step sss, where all traversal steps ttt after step sss transcends into a region that is outside qqq’s neighborhood sphere, defined by qqq’s E nearest neighbors.

Unified Query Execution Engine

  With relaxed monotonicity, VBASE builds a unified query execution engine based on Volcano Model, which resues the traditional Open, Next, and Close interfaces to leverage index traversal so that no change is required for conventional indices[ 这里需要改造向量索引对外接口，使之可以支持 Next 操作，持续迭代对外输出搜索结果 ].
  VBASE also modifies the termination condition based on relaxed monotonicity. In paticular, VABSE extends the original termination condition with relaxed monotonicity check. In addition to the original query termination condition, VBASE performs relaxed monotonicity check by inspecting Eq3(query execution would only stop if both the original termincation condition and relaxed monotonicity check were passed)
  The unified engine enables VBASE to preserve full compatibility with traditional database and creates new optimization opportunities for vector queries. For example, instead of filtering after TopK, VABSE can perform filtering during index traversal with flexible termincation conditions. Moreover, the unified engine allows the incorporation of a refined NRA algorithm, which can significantly improve the performance of multi-column vector query

VBASE Implementation

  We implement a common relaxed monotonicity check through two queues:(1) a prioroty queue with size EEE called smallestQueue, to keep the visited nearest neighbors of a target vector qqq during the traversal; (2) recentQueue of size www to track the most recent traversal window. When a new vector vvv is visited via index traversal, smallestQueue and recentQueue are updated accordingly. And the relaxed monotonicity is performed by calculating the current traversal state according to Eq3.
  As for query planning, it rquires effective cost estimation on various query plans and includes vector algebra computation, selectivity estimation in case the query contains filters, and index scan cost:

  • Vector computation: tv(dim)=t⋅c⋅dimt_v(dim)=t\cdot c \cdot dimtv​(dim)=t⋅c⋅dim, where ttt is a predefined value representing the cost of scalar operation, ccc is the coefficient related to SIMD optimizations for vector computation, and dimdimdim denotes vector dimension
  • Selectivity estimation: VBASE relies on sampling-based methods to measure the distribution of high-dimensional vectors. Specifically, VABSE uniformmaly samples vector data at a ratio and stores the sampled vectors in the metadata of the database. Given a query q, it applies the filter on the sampled data to estimate the selectivity SelSelSel on the full vector data-set
  • Index scan cost estimation: this includes start-up cost and traversal cost. The start-up cost is the cost to locate the region nearby the target vector before returing vector data; Traversal cost represents the cost to iterate over the matched tuples through the index. For each index traversal step, the cost CstepC_{step}Cstep​ includes tIOt_{IO}tIO​, the IO cost to fecth the index data from disk, and tv(dim)t_v(dim)tv​(dim), the cost to calculate the distance: Cstep=tv(dim)+tIOC_{step}=t_v(dim) +t_{IO}Cstep​=tv​(dim)+tIO​:

References

  1. ZHANG Q, XU S, CHEN Q, 等. VBASE: Unifying Online Vector Similarity Search and Relational Queries via Relaxed Monotonicity[C/OL]//17th USENIX Symposium on Operating Systems Design and Implementation (OSDI 23). Boston, MA: USENIX Association, 2023: 377-395. https://www.usenix.org/conference/osdi23/presentation/zhang-qianxi.
  2. ELOB/CHAP.G’s blob

entry.title: ESG, Elastic Graphs for Range-Filtering Approximate k-Nearest Neighbor Search
entry.content:
Overview

  Range-filtering approximate k-nearest neighbor(RFAKNN) search takes as input a vector and a numeric value, returing k points from a database of N high-dimensional points. The returned poins must lie within the specified query range, and they must be approximately the k nearest points to the query vector. A straightforward approach to processing RFAKNN queries is to filter out points outside the query range and then perform a search on the remaining in-range points. While indexing can speed up this process, ensuring correctness would require indexing all possible O(N2)O(N^2)O(N2) query ranges, which is infeasible due to severe storage constrains. To address these challenges, existing methods index only a subset of ranges, organized within a segment tree. At query time, the query range is decomposed into multiple subranges stored in the segment tree, but they also introduce significant query overhead since processing a single query requires combining indexes from O(logN)O(log N)O(logN) subranges.[ 面向标量范围查询场景，线段树，分而治之+归并/重建图索引 ]
  In this paper, we introduce a paradigm from the commonly used Prefiltering principle to the PostFiltering principle and propose novel reconstruction-based methods that guarantee at most two subranges are required for a query.

Detailes

Preliminary

  Definition: let D=v1,v2,...,vND={v_1, v_2, ... , v_N}D=v1​,v2​,...,vN​ be a set of NNN points in RdR^dRd where each point viv_ivi​ is associated with a numerical value i∈[1,N]i \in [1,N]i∈[1,N]. The RFAKNN query is defined as Q=(q,l,r)Q=(q,l,r)Q=(q,l,r), where qqq is a vector and [l,r][l,r][l,r] denotes a range. The RFAKNN query returns the result of AKNN search of qqq in D[l,r]D_{[l,r]}D[l,r]​, where ∀vi∈D[l,r],i∈[l,r]\forall v_i \in \mathcal{D}_{[l,r]}, i \in [l, r]∀vi​∈D[l,r]​,i∈[l,r].
   For Graph Index, there are two principles for answering RFAKNN search queryies:

  • PreFiltering: identify and diacard out-of-range points during the search process. It is effective in removing out-of-range points from the graph and reducing the search space. As a result, it ensures high query efficiency but may cause the graph to become sparse, potentially preventing the search from finding the correct result.
  • PostFiltering: do not discard out0of-range points during the search phase, only when a point is encountered and evaluated for inclusion in the result set, it discards the points if its numericvalue is not within the quey range. It maintains high accuracy because it searches on the whole graph, but it may result in a longer query time.

  Recall that PreFiltering and PostFiltering only work on single graph index created for the entire range [1,N][1,N][1,N], and to overcome their limitions, existing solutions primarily focus on creating multiple graph indexes, and these solutions can be categoriced into two types:

  • Compression-based methods: construct the graph index for each of the O(N2)O(N^2)O(N2) possible ranges. When a RFAKNN query is issued, the graph corresponding to the query range [lq,rq][l_q,r_q][lq​,rq​] is retrived, and the query is processed using a graph search algorithm. Since materializing and storing all O(N2)O(N^2)O(N2) possible ranges is infeasible, thses methods propose a holistic index that compactly compresses these O(N2)O(N^2)O(N2) indexes to a size of O(NlogN)O(NlogN)O(NlogN).[ 压缩意味着信息丢失和精度下降 ]
  • Reconstruction-based methods: instead of materializing the index for all possible ranges, a subset of ranges is selected to index. Specifically, a segment tree is employed for this selection purpose. Initially, the entire range [1,N][1,N][1,N] is selected as the root and indexed. Subsequently, the range is divided into sub-ranges(i.e., 2 for fanout) and this division continues until the number of points within a given subrange falls below a predifined threshold(O(NlogN)totalindexesO(NlogN) total indexesO(NlogN)totalindexes). When a query with a range [l,r][l,r][l,r] is issued, the segment tree can reconstruct the index(combined to generate the index for query range)[ 因为需要合并若干子索引来重建索引，性能有一定下降 ]

  [ 注意到，不论是压缩，还是重建，一定程度上都可以归类到“前置过滤”方案大类中去。而本文提出的 ESG 则是属于“后置过滤”大类中的 ]

Theoretical Findings

  For PostFiltering, for any query range [l,r][l,r][l,r], it operates on the graph containing all points in D\mathcal{D}D, which is the root cause of PostFiltering. To address this limitation, we propose relaxing this requirement by assuming that graph indexes are created for multiple ranges, denoted as RRR. The relationship between a range [l,r][l,r][l,r] and the set of range RRR is captured using the concept of Elastic Factor.
  Definition(Elastic Factor): Given a set of ranges RRR, where each range [li.ri]∈R[l_i. r_i] \in R[li​.ri​]∈R has li,ri∈[1,N]l_i,r_i \in [1,N]li​,ri​∈[1,N], the elastic favtor of a range [l,r][l,r][l,r], with l,r∈[1,N]l,r \in [1,N]l,r∈[1,N], is defined as:

e(R,[l,r])=max⁡[l,r]⊆[li,ri](∥[l,r]∥∥[li,ri]∥).e(R, [l, r]) = \max_{[l, r] \subseteq [l_i, r_i]} \left( \frac{\| [l, r] \|}{\| [l_i, r_i] \|} \right).e(R,[l,r])=[l,r]⊆[li​,ri​]max​(∥[li​,ri​]∥∥[l,r]∥​).

  The elastic factor e(R,[l,r])e(R, [l,r])e(R,[l,r]) can be understood as selecting the closest superset of a query range [l,r][l,r][l,r] from RRR to measure the ratio. Based on the elastic factor, we provide two key findings:

  • when RRR includes a superset range [a,b][a,b][a,b] of the query range [l,r][l,r][l,r], the query accuracy is not compromised
  • when e(R,[l,r])e(R,[l,r])e(R,[l,r]) is sufficiently large(as RRR can now include more ranges), the query speed of PostFiltering can be improved without sacrificing accuracy[ Reference the original paper for necessary proof of the RFAKNN algorithm complexity ]. That’s, given a database D\mathcal{D}D of NNN points, a range set RRR, and a query qqq with a filter range [l,r][l,r][l,r]. Assuming the conditions outlined in [2] and that the attribute values of points D\mathcal{D}D are independent, if the elastic factor of [l,r][l,r][l,r] satisfies e(R,[l,r])≥ce(R,[l,r]) \ge ce(R,[l,r])≥c for some constant ccc, the MSNET with reverse edges returns the range-filtering kkk nearest neighbors with an expected search path length:

O(N′1dlog⁡N′1dΔr′+k/c)O\left(\frac{N'^{\frac{1}{d}} \log N'^{\frac{1}{d}}}{\Delta r'} + k/c\right)O(Δr′N′d1​logN′d1​​+k/c)

  where N′=∣[l,r]∣/cN' = |[l,r]|/cN′=∣[l,r]∣/c and Δr′\Delta r'Δr′ is the minimal distance to get closer to the query. And the next challenge lies in designing a method to generate the range set RRR such that the elastic factor exceeds a constant threshold ccc for any query range[ 本文接下来都假设 c=0.5，尽管实际上 c 是一个可用于调节精度和速度的参数 ].

RFAKNN Query for Half-Bounded Queries

  A half-bounded query means that the qeury range takes the form of either [1,r][1,r][1,r] or [r,N][r,N][r,N], where r∈[1,N]r \in [1,N]r∈[1,N]. And due to the elastic factor, it’s sufficient to creat only O(logN)O(logN)O(logN) graphs instead of NNN graphs for each range [1,i][1,i][1,i], where i∈[1,N]i \in [1,N]i∈[1,N]
  Given a databse D\mathcal{D}D of NNN points, the ESG1DESG_{1D}ESG1D​ index contains log N graphs, Each graph is constructed for the range [1,N/2i][1, N/2^{i}][1,N/2i], where i∈[0,logN]i \in [0, logN]i∈[0,logN], and we observe that when constructing thegraph index for the range [1,N][1,N][1,N], all other subranges in RRR can be derived as byproducts. Specifically, by sorting the points in non-increasing order based on their attribute values, the index for any range [1,cur][1,cur][1,cur] (where cur≤cur \lecur≤ N) is incrementally created until we reach cur=Ncur = Ncur=N and the index for [1,N][1,N][1,N] is created:

  To process an RFAKNN query with point qqq and range [1,r][1,r][1,r], we retrive the ESG1DESG_{1D}ESG1D​ index to locate the recorded graph under the range [1,N/2⌈logr⌉][1,N/2^{\lceil logr \rceil}][1,N/2⌈logr⌉]. Then, we utilze PostFiltering to search this graph to find the answer. The rationale and justification for using this range, [1,N/2⌈logr⌉][1,N/2^{\lceil logr \rceil}][1,N/2⌈logr⌉], are as follows:

[1,r]⊆[1,N/2⌈log⁡r⌉], and ∥[1,r]∥∥[1,N/2⌈log⁡r⌉]∥≥0.5[1, r] \subseteq [1, N/2^{\lceil \log r \rceil}], \text{ and } \frac{\| [1, r] \|}{\| [1, N/2^{\lceil \log r \rceil}] \|} \geq 0.5[1,r]⊆[1,N/2⌈logr⌉], and ∥[1,N/2⌈logr⌉]∥∥[1,r]∥​≥0.5

RFAKNN Query for General Queries

  For handling a general RFAKNN query, we propose ESG2DESG_{2D}ESG2D​ index, which is also a hierarchical structure encoded in a segment tree. Given a database D\mathcal{D}D of NNN points, the ESG2DESG_{2D}ESG2D​ index contains log N layers. The root of the segment tree corresponds to the range [1,N][1,N][1,N], and its children are recursively defined as divisions of the range into two subranges, [1,N/2][1,N / 2][1,N/2] and [N/2+1,N][N / 2 + 1, N][N/2+1,N]

  To process a query with qqq and a range [lq,rq][l_q,r_q][lq​,rq​], we follows a recursive process, with the termination condition being when the selected subrange [l,r][l,r][l,r] becoms samller than a predefined threshold. At this point, a linear scan is performed to report the answer. If the query range is ccc time larger than the selected subrange [l,r][l,r][l,r](whre c is the elastic factor), the graph stored in ESG2DESG_{2D}ESG2D​ is utilized along with PostFiltering to find the answer(Line 3-5). Otherwise, the subrange is divided into two parts, and the algorithm is applied recursively to each part: the left part and the right part. The results from the left and right parts are merged to produce the final answer. A key difference is that when a subrange encountered during traversal does not exactly match the current query range, it still can be used if Line 3 satisfies, thanks to the use of the elastic factor.
  One thing that’s important is that, given a RFAKNN query, the search algorithm selects at most two graph indexes in the worst case, assuming a fanout of 2.

Future

  • extend this concept to other index structure, focusing on enhancing construction efficiency and optimizing space utilization
  • 本文针对的场景是每个向量数据附带一个标量属性/过滤条件，那么如果扩展到多个标量属性/过滤条件，本文的线段树组织+重建方法是否依旧适用？性能？精度？

References

  1. YANG M, LI W, SHEN Z, 等. ESG: Elastic Graphs for Range-Filtering Approximate k-Nearest Neighbor Search[EB/OL]. arXiv, 2025[2025-04-22]. http://arxiv.org/abs/2504.04018.
  2. FU C, XIANG C, WANG C, 等. Fast approximate nearest neighbor search with the navigating spreading-out graph[J]. Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment, 2019, 12(5): 461-474.

entry.title: AnalyticDB-V, A Hybrid Analytical Engine Towards Query Fusion for Structured and Unstructured Data
entry.content:
Overview

   In this paper, we present a hybrid analytic engine developed in Alibaba, name AnalyticDB-V(ADBV), which is designed and implemented from the system perspective to support hybrid queries for structured and unstructured data with real-time updates. ADBV’s major contributions:

  1. A real-time analytic engine for hybrid queries that natively supports hybrid query for fusion of structured and unstructured data with real-time updates(Lambda framework)
  2. A new ANNS algorithm called VGPQ(Voronoi Graph Production Quantization) which could efficiently narrow down the search csope in the vector space
  3. Accuracy-aware cost-based hybrid query optimization

Details

Architecture overview

  ADBV is mainly composed of three types of nodes:

  • Coordinator node: accept, parse, optimzed SQL statements, and dispatch them to read/write nodes
  • Read node: serve for SELECTSELECTSELECT queries[ 读写分离架构，牺牲一致性换取性能 ]
  • Write node: serve for write queries(i.e., INSERTINSERTINSERT, DELETEDELETEDELETE, UPDATEUPDATEUPDATE)
      To solve the challenge of supporting real-time inserts and queries, ADBV adopt the lambda framework. Under this framework, ADBV use HNSW to build index for newly-inserted vectors in real time(streaming layer), and periodcally merges the incremental data with baseline data into a global index according to the proposed VGPQ algorithm(batch layer) and discards the HNSW index. The lambda framework consistis of three layes[ 流批一体化 ]:
  • Batching layer: return search based on baseline data[ lies in Read node]
  • Steaming layer: process data modification and produce seach results over ncremental data(for SELECT statemets, parital results from batching and streaming layers are merged by coordinators to derive final results)[ Lies in both Read and Write node]
  • Serving layer: issues requests to both batching and streaming layers and return results to client[ lies in Coodinator node]

  ADBV provides the ability to partition vector data across a number of nodes to achieve high scalability. For the partitioned column, we apply the k-means to calculate the centroids according to the number of partitions and each vector is clustered to the centroid with the largest similarity. Indexing building and data manipulation are then conducted on each individual partition. As for partition pruning, ADBV dispatches the query to NNN(a query hint defined by the user) partitions, which have the largest similarity to the queries vector.

Vector processing algorithms

  ADBV primarily leverages neighborhood-based and quantization-based algorithms to do nearest neighbor seach on data in the streaming layer and batching layer respectively. At the streaming layer, ADBV implements HNSW. At the batching layer, ADBV applied quantization-based algorithm PQ to encode vectors and utilizes IVFPQ for pruning. What’ more, ADBV proposes VGPQ based on IVFPQ to furtuher improve the efficiency.
  Main idea of VGPQ: Recall that IVFPQ clusters vectors into groups vis k-means and each then vector’s PQ code is characterized by the corresponding centroid. An incoming vector query is redirected to the most relevant groups, where relevant codes are scanned. In VGPQ, we build a voronoi diagram from these centroids in IVFPQ on the original space, and partition each voronoi cell into several subcells.

Hybrid query optimization

  Four physical plans are proposed to execute the hybrid query in ADBV:

  • Plan A(brute-force search): right after the B-Tree scan, all tuples that satify structured predicates are popped from the storage layer. Then, brute-force search will be conducted to obtain exact top-k neighbors at the read node[ this plan only works on small datasets]
  • Plan B(PQ Knn Bitmap Scan): after performing a B-Tree Scan, a set of rowid referring to the qualified tuples are collected and we build a bitmap over this tuple set. Then, we carry out the PQ Knn Bitmap Scan operations which obtains the pre-computed PQ codes corresponding to rowids one by one, and performs asymmetric diatance computation(ADC) to estimate squared distances. After that, a set of candidate neraest neighbors are gathered and reported to the upper layer in ascending order of calculated distancs( instead of reporting exact k rowids, PQ Knn Bitmap Scan return σ * k)
  • Plan C(VGPQ Knn Bitmap Scan): plan C is very similar to plan B, that is it first gets a bitmap of rowids using B-Tree Scan and then performs VGPQ Knn Bitmap Scan to get an approximate nearest neighbors set with size σ * k. But plan C adds bitmap tests to the original VGPQ to remove the redundant computation between input unstructured data and those PQ codes that fail to meet structured predicates.[ 比 Plan B 提出了更高的过滤要求，适用于当B树扫描得出的数据集较大的情况 ]
  • Plan D(VGPQ Knn Scan): when most records in a large table meet structured predicates, the cost of filter operation in all above plans will become a bottleneck. Hence, Plan D exchange the execution order of Filter Operation and Top-N operator. It applies the orignal VGPQ Knn Scan at first and then verifies the approximate result set against the structured predicates

  Given a hybrid quey, plan execution costs can be calculated with above operations, and then the optimizer chooses the one with minimal cost as the final plan.

Accuracy-aware hyperparameter tuning

  Given the user-defined accuracy requirement and kkk, we need to find appropriate hyperparameters(i.e., β, γ and σ) for each possible physical plan under different structured predicates. The hyperparameter tunning process consists of two steps, i.e., pre-process step and execution step.
  At the pre-process step, we divide the range of α\alphaα into many disjoint segments, each of which is treated as a bin and recognized by its lowest value. For each plan, we use a grid search method to enumerate all combinations of hyperparameters for all bins. Among them, we only consider combinations that could return results satisfying the accuracy requirement. Then the combination of the lowest running time will be recorded as the final setting of the corresponding plan and bin. In ADBV, the pre-process step is carried out after the newly ingested data is merged into batching layer in lambda framework.
  At the execution step, for each ad-hoc query, we could estimate the value of α′\alpha^{'}α′ with sophisticated selectivity estimation techniques that are already developed in the query optimizer of modern database systems. Then, we select the pre-tuned combination of hyperparameters belong to the corresponding binfor each for each plan. Finally, we identify the most efficient plan for execution by computing corresponding cost models with selected hyperparameter combinations.

Future directions

  1. an interesting future and ongoing work is to support complex ETL processing with hybrid query semantics in the same engine for online interactive query processing

References

  1. WEI C, WU B, WANG S, 等. AnalyticDB-V: a hybrid analytical engine towards query fusion for structured and unstructured data[J]. Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment, 2020, 13(12): 3152-3165.
  2. IBM: what is ELT

entry.title: SQUASH, Serverless and Distributed Quantization-based Attributed Vector Similarity Search
entry.content:
Overview

  Recent work extends ANNS to support attribute filtering(AF), where the vector similarity is constrained with filters on additional attributes. In this paper, we introduce SQUASH, a serverless and distributed hybrid vector ANNS system designed as an elastic Function-as-a-Service(Faas) architecture, which supports advanced filtering on both continuous and catagorical attributes of any cardinality, including complex logical conditions. The following summarizes the main technical contributions of SQUASH:

  1. Design OSQ, a distributed quantization-based indexing method for both vector and attribute data. It combines multiple dimensions into shared segments for optimal compression, and enables native filtering support
  2. A low bit variant of OSQ is developed for early candidate pruning via fast bitwise comparisons, which enables high recall with low reranking requirements
  3. Design a multi-stage search pipeline including attribute filtering, partition ranking and selection, effective pruning via low-bit OSQ, a minimal set of distance calculations and an optional post-refinement step
  4. A tree-based method for synchronous Faas invocation is designed to quickly scale to thousands of concurrent instances. The multi-level approach and ID selection scheme enables the efficient coordination of parallel workers. A data retention mechanism is also intrduced to enable reuse of relevant vector indexes in runtime containers.

  [ 一般说来，如果我们希望在系统中实现标量-向量混合查询，我们会在系统中分别为维护标量索引和向量索引，然后再使用pre-filtering或post-filtering策略来执行混合查询，本文借助优化后的量化算法实现将标量数据和标量索引融合进入向量索引来支持过滤功能，这是创新点其一。其二是其面向 FaaS 设计的系统架构，使用了诸如分而治之（自底向上）、数据缓存、异步化等思想 ]

Details

Optimized Scalar Quantization(OSQ)

  OSQ introduces a segment-based storage scheme which enables the theoretical compression of SQ to be realized in practice and lets us encode an appropriate number of bits for each dimension( the number of bits assigned to a dimension determines the precision of the quantized approximations). To perform the non-uniform bit allocation, bits are iterativey assigned to the dimension with the highest variance which is reduced accordingly after each assignment. Finally, the resulting bit allocations BBB and quantization cell counts C(C(C(B[j]=k \longrightarrow C[j]=2^k$) are recorded, each dimension vi,jv_{i,j}vi,j​ of vector viv_ivi​ is quantized by identifying its cell within dimension jjj.[ 不同于传统的标量压缩技巧为每个维度使用一个 unit8 来表示，这里根据数据的分布方差来分配更多的位数给该维度，进而提升精度。同时还设计了混合存储结构，避免空间浪费 ]

  In order to access individual dimensions from OSQ index, the OSQ extraction scheme utilizes column-wise lightweight left/right bit-shift operations. These operations are acclerated with vectorization, allowing a given dimension to be extracted simultaneously for all vectors. Further, in the hybrid search setting, we typically consider a reduced candidate set after filtering, that’s extraction operations are only performed on rows satisfying the predicate filter.[ 位运算获取给定维度的量化表示，过滤整体上走的 pre-filtering 策略]

Hybrid Search with Quantized Attributes

  Def.1(Hybrid Search): Given a dataset D=(v1,a1),...,(vN,aN)D={(v_1,a_1), ..., (v_N,a_N)}D=(v1​,a1​),...,(vN​,aN​) of NNN vectors vi∈Rdv_i \in R^dvi​∈Rd with associated attribute data ai∈RAa_i \in R^Aai​∈RA, query vector q=vq,pqq={v_q,p_q}q=vq​,pq​, and limit kkk, find the kkk vectors in DDD that are most similar to qqq which also satisfy predicate pqp_qpq​(for all attributes). The predicate pqp_qpq​ consists of an operator mkm_kmk​ and one or more operands nk,ln_{k,l}nk,l​ for each attribute k:(m0,n0,1,n0,2),...,(mA−1,nA−1,1,nA−1,2)k:{(m_0,n_{0,1},n_{0,2}), ..., (m_{A-1},n_{A-1,1},n_{A-1,2})}k:(m0​,n0,1​,n0,2​),...,(mA−1​,nA−1,1​,nA−1,2​).
  Our approach for hybrid search is illustrated in Figure 4. We quantize attributes using OSQ in a similar fashion to individual vector dimensions, and employ a cumulative bitwise masking approach to perform filtering. The final attribute mask is combined with a partition-vector residency map in order to perform distributed filtered search without memory overhead or multiple search passed.( This design supports an unlimited number of real-values or categorical attributes, allowing any combination of equality and range predicated over multiple attributes simultaneously)

  Query Predicate Parsing: The first step of hybrid query processing is to parse the filter predicate(support operator: >,<,=,≤,≥,Between\gt,\lt, =, \le, \ge , Between>,<,=,≤,≥,Between). We maintain an in-memory array of attribute quantization boundary values VVV, which has dimensionality (M+1,A)(M+1,A)(M+1,A)( MMM is the maximum number of quantization cells in any dimension(max(C)max(C)max(C)) and AAA is the number of attributes indexed). At query time, we construct a loopup arrary RRR, of dimensionality (M+1,A,∣Q∣)(M+1,A,|Q|)(M+1,A,∣Q∣), where ∣Q∣|Q|∣Q∣ is the number of queries to be processed. RRR contains binary values indicating for a given query whether a given quantized cell satisfies the filter for this this attribute.
  For example, if query qqq specifies that attribute 000 has value a0<15a_0 \lt 15a0​<15, and V[:,0]=[0,5,10,15,20]V[:,0]=[0,5,10,15,20]V[:,0]=[0,5,10,15,20], then we set R[:,0,q]=[1,1,1,0,0]R[:,0,q]=[1,1,1,0,0]R[:,0,q]=[1,1,1,0,0], which is illustrated in step 1 of Figure 4.
  Filter Mask Calculation: Next we generate the attribute filter mask, i.e., a binary array indicating the vectors IDs that satisfiy the filter predicate. Our solution is based on pass/fail bitmaps, and pregressively performs efficient bitwise AND opeations over all attributes(OR 同理可推). The attribute filter mask FFF is a binary arrray of length NNN, initizalied to 111 for all vectors. Then we perfoem a vectorized lookup into R[:,0,q]R[:,0,q]R[:,0,q] for query qqq using values from the first column of the attribute Q−IndexQ-IndexQ−Index, which are help in memory for all vectors and returns a binary satisfaction array S0S_0S0​. Next, we perform a bitwise AND between FFF and S0S_0S0​ to update FFF. After repeating this process for all attributes and perfoming successive vectorized lookups/bitwise ANDs, we finnaly get a candiate vector mask for a given query.[ 对于一个给定的查询的标量过滤条件，查表然后构建位图 ]

Multi-Stage Search Rountine

  This section describes the multi-stage search routine in SQUASH in four funcyional areas, namely coarse partition, pre-processing, fine-grained index and post-refinement.

Coarse Partitioner, Pre-Processing

  The coarse partitioning step involves constrained clustering to extract balanced partitions for computational local balance in the resource-constrained FaaS environment. Within each partition, we design an OSQ index. We also apply an optional unitary transformation in order to decorrelate dimensional and compact energy which boosts the performance of our non-uniform bit allocation( Karhunen-Loeve Transform is used to make each partition not only more efficient and parallel, but also captures the local data distribution more accrately ). Finnaly, we perfoerm efficient one-dimensional K-means clustering to design optial scalar quantizers based on the data distribution.[ 数据分区构建分布式解决方案 ]

Filter Partition Ranking and Selection

  At query time, we fist carry out the attribute filtering workflow and gloabbly calculate the filter mask FFF, next we determine which partitions to visit to answer a given query(for all visted partitions, we consider all vectors passing the filter as candidates). Our goal is to vist the minimal set of partitions while satisfying both of the following: (1) at least kkk vectors passing the filter will be considered; (2) all partitions whose centroids are within a multiplicative distance factor TTT of the nearest(to be query) are visited.[ 先做标量前置过滤，然后再决定要访问多少个分区以及每个分区内要访问哪些向量数据 ]

Fast Pruning via Low-Bit OSQ

  Having reduce the search scope via attribute filtering and partition selection, we wish to quickly prune a significant portion of the remaining local candidates with minimal accuracy loss(partition-level) to avoid full diatance calculations. Therefore, in addition to the primary index, we also build a low-bit OSQ index(also in memory), which assigns a single bit to each dimension and can be leveraged for early candidate pruning vis fast bitwise comparisons. The low-bit OSQ scheme utilizes binary quantization, in conjunction with our segment-based storage scheme, to consolidate the 1-bit representations for S dimensions into each S-bit segment. We first standardize the data, before thresholding vectors around 0 to determine 0/1 mappings. Following this, binary values are stored into segments via OSQ.
   We compute(binary quantized) query-to-vector Hamming distances for all local candidates, and the percentage cutoff HpercH_{perc}Hperc​ can be tuned according to the approximation tolerance of the user.[ 二级索引，二进制量化，进一步实现分区排除 ]

Fine-Grained Distance Calculations

  Using the primary OSQ index, we approximate the distance from a query qqq to a given vector by identifying the distance from qqq to the nearest edge of the high-dimensional cell containing that (quantized) vector, this is a lower bound(LB) distance calculation and is calculated as the squared root of the sum, over all dimensional, of the squared distances to the nearest boundary values(ADC, 因为查询向量没有被量化). We only calculate LBs for candidates not pruned thus far, and candidates are ranked in ascending LB diatance order.
  Importantly, we note that many vectors are quantized to the same cell in a given dimension, for which we construct an in-memory ADC lookup table LLL of dimensionality (M+1,d)(M+1,d)(M+1,d) for each query qqq.[ ADC 方式计算每一个候选向量和查询向量的距离 ]

Post-Refinement and Result Aggregation

  As an optinal step, random reads to disk can be performed to fetch un-quantized vector data, and compute full-precision distance calculations. This would boost recall and improve the ordering of the final result set. When doing so, R⋅k(R>1)R·k(R\gt 1)R⋅k(R>1) records are retrived, enbaling the discovery of any true neae=rest neighbors with LB distances just outside the top-k.
  Finally, we perform an MPI-style reduce operation, where per-pertition “local results” are merged at the global level.[ 可选的精排 + 全局归并结果 ]

SQUASH Serverless Design

  [上面两小节讲述算法设计和整体流程设计，下面开始讲述实际工程部署，即如何将SQUASH部署为 FaaS 服务]

SQUASH Run-Time Entities

  The run-time system splits the attributed vector search task over three key components:

  • Coordinator(CO): the hub of SQUASH, it parses the user input, initiates the FaaS invocation tree, and return consolidated results
  • Query Allocatoe(QA): operates in a query parallel fashion, each QA begins by synchronously lauching a set of child QA instances. It determines its own role in the invocation tree and how many child instances it should launch based on the size and the depth of the tree. For settings involving multiple queries, it batches together the relevant queries for earch partition.
  • Query Processor(QP): one per ppartition visited, which performs the per-partition processing. Having received query metadata from its calling QA, it performs the low-bit OSQ pruning and fine-grained distance calculation steps, as well as the optional post-refinement stage. It then packages the final top-k results for its query set and restuns them to its parent QA instance.

Data Retention Exploitation

  FaaS-based solutions can benefit greatly from “warm starts” due to the reduced invocation latency it provides. We introduces Data Retention Exploitation(DRE) to enable subsequent invocations to entirely avoid external I/O assiciated with reading OSQ index files.
  DRE utilizes “singletone classes” to store key data in global areas which are retained across cloud function invocations due to container re-use. When the QA/QP handler functions are invoked, before downloading their data from object storage, they first check if the relevant data is already held in the singleton object. If so, and the dataset details match, the fect request is avoided and the global data is re-used.
   Seperately, we also developed an optinal lighweight result caching solution which saves results from earlier queries and avoids re-processing repeated requests.[ 单例模式管理数据，缓存思想 ]

Tree-based FaaS Invocation

  We present a tree-based nulti-level invocation structure, which offloads most of the invocation/response gathering workload to the QAs themselves instead of the CO. We launch multiple levels of QAs, each of which is responsible for invoking and gathing results from all QAs in the sub-tree rooted below itself.[ 分而治之，负载转移，避免单点瓶颈 ]

Task Interleaving for Multi-Query Optimization

  The QA can perform task interleaving to increase utilization while waiting for child QPs to return results, which enables an effective overlap of comnication with computation in multi-query workloads(invoke QAs/QPs via background threads). In particular, we perform attribute filtering and partition selection whilst waiting for QP responses from the previous query/batch. We then capture the per-partition results from QPs, and perform the required merge sort tp produce global results.[ 非关键步骤异步化，最大化系统吞吐量 ]

References

  1. OAKLEY J, FERHATOSMANOGLU H. SQUASH: Serverless and Distributed Quantization-based Attributed Vector Similarity Search[EB/OL]. arXiv, 2025[2025-04-07]. http://arxiv.org/abs/2502.01528.
  2. Srcoue Code for SQUASH

entry.title: Better bitmap performance with Roaring bitmaps
entry.content:
Overiew

  In this paper, we introduced a new bitmap compression schema called Roaring, which stores bitmap set entries as 32-bit integers in a space-efficient two-level index and uses packed arrays for compression instead of RLE.

bitmap 常被用作数据库和搜索引擎的索引，通过比特级别的并行，可以显著加速查询。但稀疏的 bitmap 可能会占用非常多内存，很多数据结构通过压缩来减少内存使用，如 WAH(Word Aligned Hybrid compression scheme) 和 Concise(Compressed ‘n’ Composable Integer Set)，而且它们大都跟随 Oracle 的脚步，使用 RLE 来压缩 bitmap。不同于这些结构，Roaring bitmap 使用 packed array 来压缩 bitmap。

Details

Architecture

  We partition the range of 32-bit indexes([0,n)[0,n)[0,n)) into chunks of 2162^{16}216 integers sharing the same 16 most significant digits and use specialized containers to store their 16 least significant bits.
  When a chunk contains no more than 4096 integers, we use a sorted array of packed 16-bit integers. When there are more than 4096 integers, we use a 2162^16216 -bit bitmap. Thus, we have two types of containers: an array container for sparse chunks and a bitmap container for dense chunks(threshold 4096 insures that at the level of the containers, each integer uses no more than 16 bits).

  The containers are stored in a dynamic array with the shared 16 most significant bits: this serves as a first-level index. The array keeps the containers sorted by the 16 most-significant bits. Actually, the presented Roaring data layout above is intertionally simple, serveal variations are possible nowadays. For example, for very dense bitmaps, when there are more than 216−40962^16-4096216−4096 integers per container, we could store the locations of zero bits instead of a 2162^16216-bit bitmap, and moreover, we could better compress sequences of consecutive intergers[RLE containers]

Access Operations

  To check for the prsence of the a 32-bit integer xxx, we first seek the container corresponding to x/216x/2^{16}x/216 using binary search. If a bitmap container is found, we access the (x mod 216)th(x\space mod\space 2^{16})^{th}(x mod 216)th bit. If an array container is found, we use a binary search again.
  We insert and remove an integer xxx similarly. We first check the corresponding container. When the container found is a bitmap, we set the value of the corresponding bit and update the cardinality accordingly. If we find an array container, we use a binary search followed by a linear-time insertion or deletion.
  When removing an integer, a bitmap container might become an array container if its cardinality reaches 4096. When adding an integer, an array container might become a bitmap container when its cardinality exceeds 4096. When this happens, a new container is created with the updated data while the old container is diacarded. Converting an array container to a bitmap container is done by creating a new bitmap container initizalized with zeros, and setting the corresponding bits. To convert a bitmap container to an array container, we extract the location of the set bits using an optimized algorithm

Logical Operations

  We implemented various operations on Roaring bitmaps, including union (bitwise OR) and intersection (bitwise AND). A bitwise operation between two Roaring bitmaps consists of iterating and comparing the 16 high-bits integers (keys) on the first-level indexes. For better performance, we maintain sorted first-level arrays. Two keys are compared at each iteration. On equality, a second-level logical operation between the corresponding containers is performed. This always generates a new container. If the container is not empty, it is added to the result along with the common key. Then iterators positioned over the first-level arrays are incremented by one. When two keys are not equal, the array containing the smallest one is incremented by one position, and if a union is performed, the lowest key and a copy of the corresponding container are added to the answer. When computing unions, we repeat until the two first-level arrays are exhausted. And when computing intersections, we terminate as soon as one array is exhausted.
  As containers can be represented with two different data structures, bitmpas and arrays, a logical union or intersecetion between two containers involves one of the three following scenarios:

  1. Bitmap vs Bitmap: We itarate over 1025 64-bit words. For unions, we perform 1024 bitwise ORs and write the result to a new bitmap container[Algo 1]. As for computing intersections, we use a less direct route: we first compute the cardinality of the result, using 1024 bitwise AND instructions, if the cardinality is larger than 4096, then we proceed as with the union, writing the result of bitwise ANDs to a new bitmap container, otherwise, we create a new array container and extract the set bits from the bitwise ANDs on the fly[Algo 3]
  1. Bitmap vs Array: When one of the two containers is a bitmap and the other one is a sorted dynamic array, the intersection can be computed very quickly: we iterate over the sorted dynamic array, and verify the exsitence of each 16-bit integer in the bitmap container. The result is written out to an array container. Unions are also efficient: we create a copy of the bitmap and simply iterate over the array, setting the corresponding bits
  2. Array vs Array: For unions, if the sum of the cardinalities is no more than 4096, we use a merge algorithm between the two arrays. Otherwise, we set th bits corresponding to both arrays in a bitmap container. We then compute cardinality using fast instructions. If the cardinality is no more than 4096, we convert the bitmap container to an array container[Algo 2]. For intersections, we use a simple merge when the two arrays have cardinalities that differ by less than a factor of 64. Otherwise, we use galloping intersections[REF 2] which is superior to a simple merge when one array (r)(r)(r) is much smaller than the other one (f)(f)(f) beacause it can skip many comparisions.
      When aggregating may bitmaps, we use other optimizations. For example, when computing the union of may bitmaps, we first locate all containers having the same key(using a priority queue). If one such container is a bitmap container, then we clone this bitmap container(if needed) and compute the union of this container with all corresponding containers in-place. In this instance, the computation of the cardinality can be done once at the end[Algo 4]

References

  1. CHAMBI S, LEMIRE D, KASER O, 等. Better bitmap performance with Roaring bitmaps[J]. Software: Practice and Experience, 2016, 46(5): 709-719.
  2. Culpepper JS, Moffat A. Efficient set intersection for inverted indexing. ACM Transactions on Information Systems, Dec 2010; 29(1):1:1–1:25, doi:10.1145/1877766.1877767.
  3. charlieroro’s blob
  4. zhaojw’s blob

entry.title: DEG, Efficient Hybrid Vector Search Using the Dynamic Edge Navigation Graph
entry.content:
Overview

  Bimodal data, such as image-text pairs, has become increasingly prevalent in the digital era. The Hybrid Vector Query(HVQ) is an efficient approach for querying such data. In this paper we propose a novel ANNS index, DEG, for the hybrid vector query probelm, which comprises three novel components: the greedy Pareto frontier search algorithm, the dynamic edge pruning strategy, and the edge seed method.

Details

Problem Statement

  We first define the concept of Hybrid Vector Query(HVQ):
  Dataset: consider a dataset DDD consisting of NNN objects. Each object o∈Do \in Do∈D is characterized by two features:(1) one feature vector, denoted by o.eo.eo.e, defined in a d-dimensional Euclidean space EdE^{d}Ed, and (2) the other feature vector, denoted by o.so.so.s, defined in an m-dimensional Euclidean space EmE^{m}Em
  HVQ: given a dataset DDD, a hybrid vector query q=<e,s,α,k>q=<e,s,\alpha,k>q=<e,s,α,k> consists of two feature vectors q.e∈Edq.e\in E^{d}q.e∈Ed and q.s∈Emq.s \in E^{m}q.s∈Em, a hyperparameter q.α∈[0,1]q.\alpha\in[0,1]q.α∈[0,1], an the number of objects to returned q.kq.kq.k. HVQ aims to retrieve kkk objects with the minimum distance Dist(q,o)Dist(q,o)Dist(q,o):

Dist(q,o)=q.α×δe(q,o)+(1−q.α)×δs(q,o)[Equa1]Dist(q,o)=q.\alpha\times \delta_e(q, o)+(1 - q.\alpha)\times \delta_s(q, o) [Equa 1]Dist(q,o)=q.α×δe​(q,o)+(1−q.α)×δs​(q,o)[Equa1]

  where δe(q,o)=δ(q.e,o.e)emax\delta_e(q, o)=\frac{\delta(q.e, o.e)}{e_{max}}δe​(q,o)=emax​δ(q.e,o.e)​ and δs(q,o)=δ(q.s,o.s)smax\delta_s(q, o)=\frac{\delta(q.s, o.s)}{s_{max}}δs​(q,o)=smax​δ(q.s,o.s)​. Here, δ(x,y)\delta(x,y)δ(x,y) represents the Euclidean distance between vectors xxx and yyy, and emaxe_{max}emax​ denotes the maximum Euclidean distance between o.eo.eo.e of any two objects in the dataset ans is used as a normalization factor(同理可推 smaxs_{max}smax​)
  Problem Statement: we aim to develop a graph-based ANNS index for the HVQ problem that maintains both accuracy and efficiency under different α\alphaα values

Preliminary Work

  Up til now, very work has been done for the HBQ problem and previous work only presents two simple solutions by adapting existing ANNS indexes[2], which are detailed belowed:

  • Fusion(F): builds an ANNS index based on the hybrid distance by fixing α=0.5\alpha = 0.5α=0.5 in Equation 1. In the query phase, it simply uses this index for handling queries which can have arbitrary values of α\alphaα[ 但实际我们希望的是可以在查询时候动态调整 α 的值，即动态决定对象两个不同向量属性部分的影响权重]
  • Merging(M): builds an index for each feature vector separately. During the search phase, it uses a top−K′top-K^{'}top−K′ query for each query feature on the corresponding index, where k′≥kk^{'} \ge kk′≥k, all the returned objects from every query feature are then reranked based on Equation 1 to find the approximate top-k results.
      Both methos fix α\alphaα value when building the index, because existing indexes are designed for the setting in which distances between objects are certain and pre-determined. But for HVQ problem, as the query’s α\alphaα changes, the distances between objects may also change. This dymamic nature of distances in HVQ exceeds the capabilities of existing ANNS techniques to handle.[ 图索引建立图时会根据点与点之间的距离来决定建立边，由于建立索引时用的 α=0.5， 那么当查询时候 α 取值变了，点之间的距离远近也就变了，进而导致存在的边是多余的或者违反RNG约束，有意义的边却在建立图索引时被删除了，进而使得索引一定程度上失效了。观察下图可知，查询时候 α 取不同值时，查询的精度和速度波动很大！]

DEG Method

  The key lies in how to construct a graph-based ANNS index that is capable of handling varying α\alphaα values, which represents three challenges:

  1. How to compute the candidate neighbor set for each node: as α\alphaα changes, the distances bwteeen objects would change, and the appropriximate nearest neighbors of each node may vary significantly
  2. How to determine edges from the candidate set: for the HVQ problem, the α\alphaα value varies at query time, making the edge lengths dynamic, and the RNG pruning strategy does not work
  3. How to select the seed for the graph index in the HVQ problem: the start node(seed) of the graph impacts the search path length, which reflects the search efficiency. But the center now can vary significantly with different α\alphaα values[ 不建议像HNSW或NSG那样从固定或随机的起点(全图中心点)出发]

Candidate Neighbor Acquisition

  To tackle the first challenge, we propose rge GPS algorithm, whose high-level idea can be summarized in two points:

  1. Find the nearest beighbor of a node at any α\alphaα value is equaivalent to solving the problem of minimizing the distance function(Equation 1) at that α\alphaα value. But finding solutions for each possible α∈[0,1]\alpha \in [0,1]α∈[0,1] is unfeasible. Then we treat it as a multi-pbject optimzation problem with each vector distance as an object. To solve this, we compute the Pareto frontier as the solution
  2. Finding the extract Pareto frontier is expensive. Therefore, the GPS algorithm aims to find the approximate Pareto frontier to reduce index construction costs. The core idea of the GPS algorithm is that a neighbor’s neighbor is likely to be neighbor. By iteratively exploring neighbors of neighbors, it continuously optimizes the approximate Pareto frontiers.

Dynamic Edge Pruning Strategy

  To address the second challenge of determing edges from the candidate set, we propose a dynamic edge pruning strategy whose key idea is as follows:

  1. We assign an active range to each edge, covering the suitable α\alphaα values for that edge, within which that edge will not be pruned by the RNG’s property
  2. At query time, we use an edge for routing only if the query’s α\alphaα value intersects with its active range; otherwise we ignore it

Edge Seed Acquisition

  To address the fird challenge, we propose the a new edge seed method, which uses nodes that are farthest from the center for varying α\alphaα values as seed. Comparing tp using multiple approximate centroids, edge seed ensures that they are far from each other. In greedy search, only edge nodes close to the query are activated, while others are ignored due to their distance.
  To obtain the edge seed, we first calculate the centroid ccc of dtataset DDD, where c.e=avg(x.e)c.e=avg(x.e)c.e=avg(x.e) and c.s=avg(x.s)c.s=avg(x.s)c.s=avg(x.s) for all x∈Dx\in Dx∈D. Then we maintain the inverse Pareto frontier of the centroid ccc, which cosists of nodes that do not dominate any other nodes based on the distance from the centroid. Finally, we will update the edge seed set when inserting new node if it can be added to the inverse Pareto frontier of the centroid

Index Construction

  Based on the modules proposed above, we can summarize the index construction process as following:

Search Algorithm

  The seach algorithm of DEG is based on the greedy seach algorithm but with tow modifications:

  1. It dynamically skips edges whose active range do not interset with the query’s α\alphaα value
  2. It introduces an eraly stopping mechanism, that is, when calculating te hybrid distance, it first computes one of theindividual vector distances and compare it to the threshold distance in the greedy seach algorithm to determine whether to skip this node early

  Specifically, the algorithm first initializes an empty min-heap SSS as the candidate set, an empty max-heap RRR as the result set. Next, the seeds are added to SSS, RRR. In each iteration, the object with the smallest distance in SSS is fetched. If its distance to the query is larger than the maximum distance in RRR, the loop breaks, and the top 𝑘𝑘k objects in RRR are returned. Otherwise, its neighbors are checked, with some being skipped based on the active ranges and the query α\alphaα value. If the distance of a neighbor to the query is smaller than the maximum distance in RRR, the neighbor is pushed into SSS and RRR. Here, the early termination mechanism is used for acceleration. If the size of R exceeds efsearchef_{search}efsearch​, the object with the maximum distance is popped from RRR

Future Directions

  1. extend this proposed index to multi-vector queries, where each object involves more than two vectors(when extend to more vectors, the active range becomes a hyperplane in 2D space, which is challenging to compute, store, and utilize)
  2. develop a disk based version of this index, making it suitable for implementation in vector databases

References

  1. YIN Z, GAO J, BALSEBRE P, 等. DEG: Efficient Hybrid Vector Search Using the Dynamic Edge Navigation Graph[J]. Proceedings of the ACM on Management of Data, 2025, 3(1): 1-28.
  2. WANG J, YI X, GUO R, 等. Milvus: A Purpose-Built Vector Data Management System[C/OL]//Proceedings of the 2021 International Conference on Management of Data. Virtual Event China: ACM, 2021: 2614-2627[2025-03-16]. https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3448016.3457550.

entry.title: HMANN, Efficient Billion-Point Nearest Neighbor Search on Heterogeneous Memory
entry.content:
Overview

  We present a new graph-based indexing and search algorithm called HM-ANN, which maps the hierarchical design of the graph-based ANNs with memory heterogeneity in HM, which takes both memory and data heterogeneity into consideration and enables billion-scale similarity search on a single node without using compression.(HM combines cheap, slow but extremely large memory with expensive fast but small memory to achieve a good balance between production cost, memory performance and capacity)
  Controbutions:

  1. Present a fast and accurate billion-scale nearest neighbor search solution on a single node without compression
  2. Exprole memory management techniques such as dynamic migration and parallel search
  3. Introduce a performance model to select search-related hyerparameters that satisfy search time and recall constraints

Details

  The design of HM-ANN generalizes HNSW. Elements in upper layer consume a small portion of the memory, making them good candidates to be placed in fast memory(small capacity), the bottom-most layer has all the elements and has the largest memory consumption, which makes it suitable to placed in slow memory. The key idea of HM-ANN is to build high-quality upper layers and make most memory access happen in fast memory, in order to provide bwtter navigation for search at L0L0L0 and reduce memory access in slow memory.

Graph Constrction

  We generalize the HNSW construction algorithm to include two phases: a top-down insertion phase and a bottom-up promotion phase. The top-down insertion phase in the same as HNSW(Line 1 in Algorithm1).
  The goal of second pahse is to build a high-quality projection of L0L0L0 elements into the layer 1(L1)(L1)(L1), such that search in L0L0L0 can find true nearest neighbours of the query with only a fen number of hops. Instead of randomly choosing the elements like HNSW, HM-ANN use a high-degree promotion strategy(Line 7-19 in Algorithm 1), which promotes elements with the highest degree in L0L0L0 to L1L1L1. From the layer i(i≥2)i(i \ge 2)i(i≥2) to i+1i + 1i+1, HM-ANN promotes high-degree nodes to upper layer with a promotion rate of 1/M1/M1/M, where MMM is the maximum number of neighbors for each elements. HM-ANN increases search quality in L1L1L1 by promoting more nodes from L0L0L0 to L1L1L1 and setting the maximum number of neighbors for each element in L1L1L1 to 2\time M and the number of nodes in upper layers is decided by available fast memory space.[ 通过使用高度晋升策略来创建更高质量的上层，以便为第0层的搜索提供更好的导航，从而使得大部分内存访问发生在slow-memory]

Searching

  The search in fast memory begins at the entry point the top layer and then performs 1-greedy search from the top layer to layer 2. To narror down the search space in L0L0L0, HM-ANN perfoems the search in L1L1L1 with a search budget controlled by efSearchL1efSearch_{L1}efSearchL1​, which defines the size of dynamic candidate list in L1L1L1. Those candidates in the list are used as entry points for search in L0L0L0.
  In L0L0L0, HM-ANN evenly partions the candidates from searching L1L1L1 and uses them as entry points to perform parallel multi-start 1-greedy search with ThrThrThr threads in parallel.

  HM-ANN implements a software-managed cache in fast memory to prefetch data from slow memory to fast memory before the memory access happens. In particular, HM-ANN reserves a space in fast memory 2GB~2GB 2GB called migration space. When searching L1L1L1, HM-ANN asynchronously copys neighbor elements of those candidates in efSearchL1efSearch_{L1}efSearchL1​ and the neighbor elements’ connections in L1L1L1 from slow memory to migration space in fast memory[ 多入口并行化查询 + 数据预取]

Performance Model-Guided Patameter Selection

  In HM-ANN, we model the search latenct as T=TL1∗+TL0T=T_{L1*} + T_{L0}T=TL1∗​+TL0​(L1∗L1*L1∗ means searching at layer 1 and above):

  Where TDCfast−memT_{DCfast-mem}TDCfast−mem​ and TDCslow−memT_{DCslow-mem}TDCslow−mem​ are measured offline on fast memory and slow memory. C=steps×DC−per−stepC=steps\times DC-per-stepC=steps×DC−per−step, is a multiplication of the average number of steps before we reach the nearest neighbor(bounded by a constant based on the theory of Delaunay graph) and the maximum number of distance computation per step(bounded by the maximal out-degree)
  Given an accracy target θ\thetaθ, HM-ANN first applies Equation 1 to analytically get a set of candidates (efSearchL0,efSearchL1)(efSearch_{L0},efSearch_{L1})(efSearchL0​,efSearchL1​) pairs, and then use a learning query set randomly sampled to measure the expected accuracy E(θ)E(\theta)E(θ), with efSearchL1≥1efSearch_{L1} \ge 1efSearchL1​≥1 and efSearchL0≥0efSearch_{L0} \ge 0efSearchL0​≥0 as constraints. HM-ANN finally chooses those cconfigurations that satisfy E(θ)≥0E(\theta) \ge 0E(θ)≥0 and uses grid search to choose the configuration that leads to the shotest query time.[ 使用机器学习进行预测和选择]

References

  1. REN J, ZHANG M, LI D. HM-ANN: efficient billion-point nearest neighbor search on heterogeneous memory[C]//Proceedings of the 34th International Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems. Red Hook, NY, USA: Curran Associates Inc., 2020.
  2. Milvus’Blob: HM-ANN

entry.title: DisKANN, Fast Accurate Billion-point Nearest Neighbor Search on a Single Node
entry.content:
Overview

  We present a new graph-based indexing and search system called DiskANN than can index, store and search a billion point database on a single workstation with just 64GB RAM and an inexpensive SSD. In short, DiskANN is a high-quality SSD-resident index, which optimizes the algorithm to build graph index and utilizes SSD.

Details

Background

  Many applications require fast and accurate search on billions of points in Euclidean metrics. Before DiskANN, there are essentially two high-level approaches to indexing large datasets:

  1. IVF + Data Compression: Cluster the dataset into M partitions and compare the query to only the points in a few partitions closest to the query. Since the full-precision vectors cannot fit in main memory, the points are usually compresses using a quantization schema such as PQ.
  2. Sharding: divide the dataset into disjoint shards, and build an in-memory index for each shard. Queries are routed to all shards, and the results from all shards are aggregated.
       The scalability of both classes og algorithms is limited by the fact that they construct indices meant to be served from main memory. Moving these indices to disks, even SSDs, would result in a catastrophic rise of search latency and a corresponding drop in throughput. And there are two main challenges in designing a performant SSD-redsident index lie in reducing (a) the number of random SSD accesses to a few dozen, and (b) the number of round trip requests to disk under ten, preferably five.

Vamana Graph Construction Algorithm

Vamana can generate graph indices with smaller diameter than NSG and HNSW, allowing DiskANN to minimize the number of sequential disk reads.

  HNSW, NSG and Vamana are all graph-based algorithms, whose search and graph-construction procedures can be abstracted as follows:

  But there are some differences between these algorithms:

  1. both HNSW and NSG have no tunable parameter α\alphaα and implicitly use α=1\alpha = 1α=1(main factor making Vamana achieve a better trade-off between graph degree and diameter)
  2. HNSW set the candidate set ν\nuν for the pruning procedure to be the final result-set of candidates ouput by GreedySearch(s,p,1,L)GreedySearch(s,p,1,L)GreedySearch(s,p,1,L), Vamana and NSG let it be the entire set of vetices visited by GreedySearch(s,p,1,L)GreedySearch(s,p,1,L)GreedySearch(s,p,1,L)(help NSG and Vamana add long-range edges)
  3. NSG set the starting grpah to be an approximate KNN graph over the dataset, HNSW begins with an empty graph and Vamana begins with a random graph(time and memory consumption)
  4. Vamana makes two passes over the dataset, wherear both HNSW and NSG make only one pass(improve graph quality, important)
       Vamana indexing algorithm:

  Over overall algorithm makes two passes over the dataset, the first pass with α=1\alpha = 1α=1, and the second with a user-defined α≥1\alpha \ge 1α≥1. We observed that a second pass results in better graphs, and that running both passes with the user-defined α\alphaα makes the indexing algorithm slower as the first pass computes a graph with higher average degree which takes longer.（从下图可以看出：第一行使用 α=1\alpha = 1α=1 消除了很多不必要的边，第二行使用 α≥1\alpha \ge 1α≥1将一些 long-range edges 加回到图中从而增强了图的全局联通性和加速搜索时的快速导航）

DiskANN: Contructing SSD-Resident Indices

Index Design

  The high-level idea is simple: run Vamana on a dataset P and store the resulting graph on SSD. At search time, simply fetch the out-neighbors of a point ppp from the SSD:

  1. Build a Graph over a billion points: we first partion a billion point dataset into k clusters using k-means, and then assign each base point to the l−closestl-closestl−closest centers(typically l=2l=2l=2 suffices). We then build Vamana indices for the points assigned to each of the clusters, and finally merge all the different graphs into a single graph by taking a simple union of edges.[ 相比于经典的 Scatter-Gather 策略，这里自底向上构建索引然后合并，省去了路由查询多个索引 shard 而后合并结果的时间开销。此外，这里的将每个节点复制一份分到不同的类中构建索引，使得多个小索引可以有交集并合并（SPANN中针对位于聚类边界的数据点也有类型类似的处理策略）]
  2. Distance Calculation: Note that justing storing the vector data for a billion points in 100 dimensions would far exceed the RAM on a workstation, so we store the compressed vectors(PQ) xp~\widetilde{x_p}xp​​ for evenry database point p∈Pp \in Pp∈P in main memory, along with storing the graph on the SSD. [ 在算法 1 中计算查询向量和数据向量间的距离时算的是 d(xp~,xq)d(\widetilde{x_p} ,x_q)d(xp​​,xq​)，但因为构建图索引时候使用的是没有压缩过的原始数据，所以图索引可以在查询时精确导航到对应正确的局部区域]

DiskANN Index Layout

  We store the compressed vectors of all the data points in memory, and store thegraph along with the full-precision vectors on the SSD. On the disk, for each point iii, we store its full precision vector xix_ixi​ followed by the identities of its ≤R\le R≤R neighbors.

DiskANN Beam Search

  A natural way to search fo neighbors of a given query xqx_qxq​ would be to run Algorithm 1, fetching the neighborhood information Nout(p∗)N_{out}(p^*)Nout​(p∗) from the SSD as needed. Distance calculations to guide the best vertices to read from disk can be done using the compressed vectors. To reduce the number of round triprs to SSD without increasing compute excessively, we fetch the neighborhoods of a small number, W(say4,8)W(say 4,8)W(say4,8) of the closest points in L∖V\mathcal{L} \setminus \mathcal{V}L∖V in one shot, and update L\mathcal{L}L to be the top LLL candidates in L\mathcal{L}L along with all the neighbors retrived in this step. Notice that fetching a small number of random sectors from an SSD takes alomost the same time as one sector.

Caching

  To futher reduce the number of disk accesses per query, we cache the data associated with a subset of vertices in DRAM, either based on a known distribution, or simply by caching all vertices that are C=3or4C=3 or 4C=3or4 hops from the starting point sss.[ 借助批量化IO读取和缓存数据的方式降低磁盘IO]

Re-Ranking

  Since PQ is a lossy compression methos, we use full-pression coordinates stored for each point next to its beighborhood on the disk. In fact, when we retieve the neighborhood of a point during search, we also retrieve the full coordinates of the point without incurring extra disk reads. Hence, as BeamSearch loads neighborhoods of the search frontier, it can also cache full-precision coordinates of all the nodes vistied during the search process, using no extra reads to the SSD, which allows us to return the top kkk candidates based on the full precision vectors.

References

  1. JAYARAM SUBRAMANYA S, DEVVRIT F, SIMHADRI H V, 等. Diskann: Fast accurate billion-point nearest neighbor search on a single node[J]. Advances in neural information processing Systems, 2019, 32.
  2. zhaojw’s blob: diskann

entry.title: SPANN, Highly Efficient Billion Scale ANNS
entry.content:
Overview

  In this paper, we present a simple but efficient memory-disk hybrid indexing and search system, named SPANN, thta follows the inverted index methodology. It stores the centroid points of the posting lists in the memory and the large posting lists in the disk.

Details

  Index structure: the data vectors XXX are divided into NNN posting lists X1,X2,...,XN{X_{1}, X_{2},..., X_{N}}X1​,X2​,...,XN​, X1∪X2∪...∪XN=XX_{1} \cup X_{2} \cup ... \cup X_{N} = XX1​∪X2​∪...∪XN​=X. The centroids of these posting lists, c1,c2,...,cNc_{1},c_{2},...,c_{N}c1​,c2​,...,cN​ are stored in the memory as fast coarse-grained index that point to the location of the corresponding posting lists in the disk.
  Partial search: when a query qqq comes, we find the KKK closest centroids, ci1,ci2,...,cik,k<<N{c_{i1},c_{i2},...,c_{ik}}, k << Nci1​,ci2​,...,cik​,k<<N, and load the vectors in the posting lists Xi1,Xi2,...,XikX_{i1},X_{i2},...,X_{ik}Xi1​,Xi2​,...,Xik​ that correspond to the closest KKK centroids into memory for further fine-grained search.
   There are three chanllenges to solve when implementing SPANN:

  1. Posting length limitation: we need to bound the length od each posting list so that it can be loaded into memory in only a few disk reads, which requires us to not only partition the data into a large number of posting lists but also balance the length of posting lists.
  2. Boundary issues: the nearest neighor vectors of a query qqq may locate in boundary of multiple posting lists. Since we only search a samll number of relevant posting lists, some true neighbors of qqq that located in other posting lists will be missing[==>Commnet: multi-probe & multi-replica ]
  3. Diverse search difficulty: different queries may have different search difficulty, some queries only need to be searched in one or two posting lists while some queries require to be searched in a large number of posting lists.

Posting length limitation

  Blancing the length of lists means we need to minimize the variance of the posting length ∑i=N(∣Xi∣−∣X∣/N)2\sum_{i=}^{N}(|X_{i}| - |X|/N)^2∑i=N​(∣Xi​∣−∣X∣/N)2. To address the this problem, we can leverage the multi-constraint balanced clustering algorithm to partition the vectors evenly into multiple posting lists:

  This algorithm cannot work due to the difficulty of large N-partition balanced clustering problem and the extremly high clustering cost when ∣X∣|X|∣X∣ and NNN are very large. Therefore, we introduce a hierarchical multi-constraint balanced clustering technique, which clusters the vectors into a small number of clusters iteratively until each posting list contains limit number of vectors. What’s more, we use additional tow techniques to optimize the algorithm:

  1. Replcae the centroid with the vector that is closest to the centroid to represent each posting list through which the wasted navigating computation is transformed to the distance computation for a subset of real candidates when find the nearest posting lists for a query[===>coment: lower computation cost]
  2. In order to quickly find a smalle number of nearest posting lists for a query, we create a memory SPTAG index(space patition tree and a relative neighborhood graph) for all the vectors that represent the centroids of the posting lists.

Posting list expansion

  To deal with boundary issue, we need to increase the visibility for those vectors that are located in the boudary of the posting lists. We introduce a closure multi-cluster assignment solution for those vectors on the final clustering step–assign a vector to multile closest clusters instead of only the closest one if the distance between the vector and these clusters are nearly the same:

x∈Xij⟺Dist(x,cij)≤(1+ϵ1)×Dist(x,ci1),\mathbf{x} \in \mathbf{X}_{ij} \Longleftrightarrow \mathrm{Dist}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{c}_{ij}) \leq (1 + \epsilon_{1}) \times \mathrm{Dist}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{c}_{i1}),x∈Xij​⟺Dist(x,cij​)≤(1+ϵ1​)×Dist(x,ci1​),

Dist(x,Ci1)≤Dist(x,ci2)≤...≤Dist(x,ciK)Dist(x,C_{i1}) \le Dist(x,c_{i2}) \le ... \le Dist(x,c_{iK})Dist(x,Ci1​)≤Dist(x,ci2​)≤...≤Dist(x,ciK​)

  However too many duplicated vectors in the close posting lists will waste the high-block disk read, for which we further optimize the closure assignment by using RNG rule to choose multiple representative clusters for the assignment of an boundary vector to reduce the similarity of two close posting lists. That is, we will skip the cluster ijijij for vector xxx if Dist(cij,x)>Dist(cij−1,cij)Dist(c_{ij},x) > Dist(c_{ij-1},c_{ij})Dist(cij​,x)>Dist(cij−1​,cij​). The insight is that two close posting lists are more likely to be both recalled by the navigating index.[===>comment: 这里的思想，和 HNSW 中启发式选择邻居的算法思想有相通之处，可以联系对比学习]

Query-aware dynamic pruning

  We introduce the query-aware dynamic pruning techinique to reduce the number of posting lists to e searched according to the distance between query and centroids instead of fixed KKK lists to be searched for all queries. A posting list to be searched only if the distance between its centroid and the query is almost the same as the distance between the query and the closest centroid, which significantly reduce the query lantency while still preserving the high recall.
  [===>comment: query-aware or using Machine-Learning for quick-stop/less seaching is one direction being investigated currently, “A promissing research direction is to exploit AI to learn more effective stopping condictions, which can further improve the efficiency”(from REF-2)]

q⟶searchXij⟺Dist(q,cij)≤(1+ϵ2)×Dist(q,ci1),\mathbf{q} \overset{search}{\longrightarrow} \mathbf{X}_{ij} \Longleftrightarrow \mathrm{Dist}(\mathbf{q},\mathbf{c}_{ij}) \leq (1 + \epsilon_{2}) \times \mathrm{Dist}(\mathbf{q},\mathbf{c}_{i1}),q⟶search​Xij​⟺Dist(q,cij​)≤(1+ϵ2​)×Dist(q,ci1​),

Dist(q,ci1)‘Dist(q,ci2)≤...≤Dist(q,ciK)Dist(q,c_{i1}) \lq Dist(q,c_{i2}) \le ... \le Dist(q,c_{iK})Dist(q,ci1​)‘Dist(q,ci2​)≤...≤Dist(q,ciK​)

Distributed Search

  Another advantage of SPANN is that the partial seach on the nearest posting lists idea can be easily extended to the distributed scenario when combined with Pyramid approach[REF-3].
  The only challenge is that there may have some hot-spot machines, for which we need to balance not only the data size but also the query access in each machine. So we partion the vectors into multiple small partitions(larger than machine number) and then use the bset-fit bin-packing algortihm to pack the small partitions into large bins(the number of bins equals to the number of machines) according to the history query access distribution.[===>comment: AI驱动、硬件加速、分布式搜索 from REF-2]

References

  1. CHEN Q, ZHAO B, WANG H, 等. Spann: Highly-efficient billion-scale approximate nearest neighborhood search[J]. Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, 2021, 34: 5199-5212.
  2. ECHIHABI K, ZOUMPATIANOS K, PALPANAS T. New trends in high-D vector similarity search: al-driven, progressive, and distributed[J]. Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment, 2021, 14(12): 3198-3201.
  3. Shiyuan Deng, Xiao Yan, KW Ng Kelvin, Chenyu Jiang, and James Cheng. 2019. Pyramid: A General Framework for Distributed Similarity Search on Large-scale Datasets. In Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data). IEEE, 1066–1071.

entry.title: SPFRESH, Incremental In-Place Update for Billion-Scale Vector Search
entry.content:
Overview

  As the amount of vector data grows continously, it becomes important to supprt updates to vector index. To amortize costs, most existing systems maintain a secondary index to accumulate updates(OUT-OF-PLACE-UPDATE), which are merged with the main index by globally rebuilding the entire index periodically, e.g.,Vearch[2] and Miluvs[3]. However, this approach has high fluctuations of seach latency and accuracy, not to mention that it requires substantial resources and is extremely time-consuming to rebuild.
  This paper introduces SPFRESHSPF_{RESH}SPFRESH​, which supports incremental in-place update for billion-scale vector search and implements LIRE, a Lightweight Incremental RE-balancing protocol to split overly large postings and reassign vectors across neighboring postings when necessary. In short, SPR_RESH is a disk-based and cluster-based vector index that supports lightweight incremental in-place updates without the need for global rebuild to adapt to the data distrbution shift.

Details

Cluster-based vector indices

  Cluster-based vector indices organize vector indices via clustering, where vectors in close proximity are kept in the same partition(IVF).These indices are firendly to updates because each vector insertion or deletion only involves local modifications of vector data in the corresponding partition. However, a native update on partitions may eventually lead to imbalanced clusters and consequently deteriorate search tail latency and accuracy.
  A key property of a well-partitioned vector index is the nearest partition assignment(NPA):each vector should be put into the nearest posting so that it can be represented by the posting centroid. In a cluster-based vector index, we may violate the NPA property of the index if we directly split the posting list whose length is beyond the maxinum-length-threshold.

SPANN

  LIRE is built on SPANN, a billion-scale cluster-based vector index optimized for secondary storage. It stores the vectors as a huge number of postings’ on disk, each represents a cluster of close-by vectors. Moreover, SPANN origanizes a graph-based in-memory index, SPTAG, for the centroids of all postings, to quickly identify relevant postings for a query.
  For a query, if first identifies the closet posting centroids through the in-memory index, and then loads the corresponding postings from the dis to memory for further search.

LIRE Protocol

  The core of SPFRESHSPF_{RESH}SPFRESH​ is LIRE, a Lightweight Incremental Rebalancing protocol that accumulate small vector updates of local vector partitions, and re-balances local data distribution at a low cost. LIRE is capable of maintaining index quality by fixing data distribution abnormalities locally on-the-fly and consists of the following basic operations:

  1. Insert & Delete: LIRE directly inserts a new vector to the nearest partition foloowing the original SPANN index design. It ensures the deleted vectors will not appear in the search results and will eventually be removed from the corresponding postings.
  2. Split: When a posting exceeds a length limit, LIRE evenly splits the oversized posting into two samller ones and a reassign process will be trigered for the vectors in the split postings as well as nearby postings.
  3. Merge: When a posting size is smaller than a lower threshold, LIRE identifies its nearest posting as candidates for merging. After it, a reassign process will also be trigered beacause the deletion of the old centroid might break the NPS rule after being merged with the other posting.[ we also need to prove that such split-reassignment process will always converage]
  4. Reassigning Vectors: For a merge process, only vectors from deleted posting require reassignment because the deletion of a centroid does not break NPA compliance of vectors from undeleted postings. On the other hand, a split not only deletes a centroid but also creates tow ones. Therefore a split creates more complex scenarios of potential NPA violations.
